metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (MUSOEXE-12)-dataset of flux observation matrix (eddy covariance system of Huazhaizi desert station)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Huazhaizi desert steppe station eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 6 June to 15 September, 2012. The site (100.31860° E, 38.76519° N) was located in a desert surface, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1731.00 m. The EC was installed at a height of 2.85 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500) was 0.15 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Concept Completion.Question: What are some common challenges in collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological research?

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting multiscale observational data for eco-hydrological processes?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in collecting multiscale observational data for eco-hydrological processes is the poor availability of such observations, which was addressed by the HiWATER experiment through a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset used for evaluating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area?
Example.Answer: A dataset containing observations from the Daman superstation, which included meteorological parameters, radiations, and turbulent fluxes, was used to evaluate surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area. This dataset was part of the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main challenges associated with obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies over heterogeneous surfaces?
Feature Specification.Answer: poor availability of multiscale observations, instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, accurate classification of remote sensing images, separation of soil and canopy temperatures, image classification errors, atmospheric interference

Quantification.Question: How many intensive airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA during the HiWATER experiment?
What is the sampling frequency of the turbulent fluxes measured using an eddy covariance system in the field?

Comparison.Question: In what ways do datasets from airborne remote sensing missions differ from ground-based eddy covariance data in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: Airborne remote sensing missions, including LiDAR and multi-angle thermal imaging, provide hyper-resolution data that capture surface characteristics over large areas, crucial for understanding multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. In contrast, eddy covariance data provide detailed point measurements of fluxes, offering high temporal resolution but limited spatial coverage. The integration of both can offer comprehensive insights into oasis-desert interactions.

Interpretation.Question: How do the methods used for correcting raw eddy covariance data, such as coordinate rotation and density corrections, impact the accuracy and reliability of flux measurements in heterogeneous surfaces?
Interpretation.Answer: Data processing methods like coordinate rotation and density corrections are essential for accounting for sensor orientation and atmospheric conditions, which can significantly affect the accuracy of flux calculations on heterogeneous surfaces. These corrections help ensure that the observed data accurately reflect the true surface-atmosphere interactions, providing reliable measurements of heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide fluxes.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise from using thermal infrared imaging for separating soil and canopy temperatures in heterogeneous landscapes, and how might these challenges affect the interpretation of evapotranspiration rates?
Interpretation.Answer: Thermal infrared imaging can be challenging due to image classification errors, especially in areas with varying vegetation abundance. Misclassifying soil and canopy pixels can lead to inaccurate component temperature estimations, affecting the accuracy of evapotranspiration rate calculations. These errors can result from mixed pixel effects and ignored atmospheric conditions, impacting the reliability of surface flux estimations.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do the hierarchical and multi-scale observation methods employed in eco-hydrological experiments contribute to understanding complex land-atmosphere interactions in oasis-desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: Hierarchical and multi-scale observation methods provide comprehensive data across different spatial and temporal scales, capturing the diverse interactions within oasis-desert systems. By integrating flux measurements, remote sensing data, and meteorological observations, researchers can better understand the dynamics of water, energy, and carbon fluxes and their interactions with landscape heterogeneity, improving model accuracy and ecosystem management strategies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations a challenge in upscaling eco-hydrological processes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The availability of multiscale observations is a challenge in upscaling eco-hydrological processes because instrumentation across hierarchically nested scales is required to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, and there is often a lack of such comprehensive, multiscale data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to errors in temperature component separation in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in temperature component separation in arid regions are mainly due to image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, the overestimation of canopy temperature under developing vegetation, and ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, which contribute to uncertainties in estimated temperatures.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of implementing a multiscale observation system in the context of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data through hierarchically nested instrumentation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are employed to preprocess eddy covariance data for reliable evapotranspiration estimates over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The preprocessing of eddy covariance data involves multiple steps such as despiking (removing outliers), time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, the quality of flux values is assessed through tests for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data is further filtered by removing periods with instrument errors, data surrounding precipitation events, and observations with a high data loss rate or weak nighttime turbulence.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methods used to validate evapotranspiration estimates in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Evapotranspiration estimates are validated using a combination of ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques, and eddy covariance (EC) measurements. The validation process involves comparing the estimated ratios of evaporation to evapotranspiration (E/ET%) and transpiration to evapotranspiration (T/ET%) with observed ratios. The TSEB model is applied using soil and canopy component temperatures obtained from high-resolution thermal cameras to improve the accuracy of these estimates.

Enablement.Question: What methodological approaches are employed to ensure the quality and accuracy of datasets obtained from eco-hydrological sensor networks and remote sensing techniques?
Enablement.Answer: Observational data are carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. This includes managing errors in derived component temperatures due to image classification errors and ensuring accurate measurements of incoming radiation transmittances. The findings also emphasize the importance of robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculations for accurate evapotranspiration estimation.

Expectation.Question: Why is there often an overestimation of component temperatures in composite temperature separation approaches within arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced uncertainties in the estimated temperatures.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges when using the TSEB model for estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area?
Expectation.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy and the high uncertainty in surface-air temperature difference. The TSEB model performance is mainly affected by this uncertainty, which is often dominant due to errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures.

Expectation.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations crucial for upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface?
Expectation.Answer: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is challenging due to the poor availability of multiscale observations. Multiscale and multidisciplinary data are needed to capture and understand the intricate eco-hydrological processes across different scales and landscapes.

Judgmental.Question: What potential improvements could be made to the current data collection strategies to enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates over heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential improvements include refining temperature separation approaches to better address arid region conditions, increasing the spatial and temporal resolution of remote sensing data, and enhancing the classification accuracy of soil and vegetation pixels. Further integration of advanced thermal imaging with ground-based observations and employing robust quality control mechanisms can also improve data accuracy and reliability in estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous landscapes.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how multiscale observations can be effectively captured in an eco-hydrological study on a heterogeneous surface.
Assertion.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses this by using hierarchically nested scales and a sparse network to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. It involves a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing and synchronical ground measurements.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the TSEB model can separate soil and canopy temperatures for accurate estimation of evapotranspiration.
Assertion.Answer: The TSEB model uses soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera, which are then classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. These temperatures are converted to radiation temperatures and validated against surface radiometric temperatures using a four-component radiometer.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in collecting reliable eddy covariance flux measurements in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include errors in the derived component temperature due to image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. These errors can affect the accuracy of the TSEB model and the EC system, particularly influencing the estimation of sensible heat fluxes in irrigated farmland.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used for capturing evapotranspiration (ET) metrics in heterogeneous landscapes within the context of eco-hydrological research.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for evapotranspiration (ET) in heterogeneous landscapes involve the use of eddy covariance (EC) systems to measure turbulent fluxes, thermal infrared cameras for capturing soil and canopy component temperatures, and ground-based meteorological measurements for air temperature, wind speed, and humidity. These methods are complemented by high-resolution remote sensing tools such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers as part of the HiWATER experiment, which addresses multiscale eco-hydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets and their characteristics that can be utilized for studying water cycle dynamics in oasis-desert areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying water cycle dynamics in oasis-desert areas include the multiscale datasets from the HiWATER experiment, which consist of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. These datasets are enhanced by eco-hydrological sensor networks measuring soil moisture and leaf area index, as well as hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data. The datasets are quality controlled across sensor calibration, data collection, and processing, and are available through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.
